like the first thing I always keep in
mind is contrast you know if you got if
you got a bunch of guitars that you're
planning on layering it's best to have
contrasting tones like if you're gonna
have a clean dark round sound for your
your bass thing for your for your first
track then you want to add you know just
as a general rule you want to add some
sort of brighter thinner sound on top of
that like Jimmy Page Led Zeppelin was it
was the master of understanding the
importance of contrasts in tones I mean
you can get to so lit up isolated tracks
of first couple Zeppelin records great
examples of like a big fat thick bass
sound and then this little tiny thin
razor e guitar that on their own don't
really sound that amazing but when you
put them together God so good so I'm
always trying to keep that type of stuff
in mind like you know you don't want two
things to get cloudy you don't want too
much low-end building up or you don't
want too much high-end building up just
try to get some different tones that you
know that sort of marry together in a
pleasing way that's why you so much EQ

guitar so that's just a general rule
contrast is your friend you know when it
